utterances: So you wereâ€¦
So that is a typical thing that happens.
You were in a basement room with TV screens.
Do you think that affected your coverage at all in the sense that you may not have had quite the same access to the crowd and their cheering, their booing, their laughing?
Well, again, I was actually in the debate hall for some time because I was actually one of the - I worked with the Nevada Democratic Party.
So I was in the debate hall for some period and I was in the press filing center which happened to be in another room that was below the debate hall.
To call it a basement would be kind of an overstatement.
But, yes, the only difference is you don't get a chance - you get the same experience as a journalist as the viewer gets who's watching it at home.
Because I think it's a fairly fair way of doing these things.

But what we did see last night, which we didn't talk about is and wasn't reflected in the clips you played, Barack Obama actually last night, for the first time, I felt like he was the most comfortable he's ever been on that stage.
He also had a very commanding presence.
And one of the things I've been critical about him in his campaign is that he hasn't sort of shown the command of a president, the bearing of someone who is going to take charge of the country.
And last night, I felt like he did that for the first time, you know, the last couple of weeks, it does seem like he's sort of getting his mojo as a candidate.
And so that, I thought, was important.
The tough thing though for someone like John Edwards, who is really ready to go after Senator Clinton, is the crowd was not in the mood to have a lot of conflict last night between the candidates.
So he really did stop that exchange.
And I think he would have had a more eventful debate had the crowd not been as involved with it as it was.
Well, Jamal, thank you so much.
Thank you.
I've been speaking with political strategist, Jamal Simmons.
And it's time now for our Staff Song Pick of the Week.
This week, our producer Roy Hurst has control of the CD players.
Take Marta Calderon, a woman in her 50s and an activist in the Puerto Rican community.
For the last 22 years she has worked at the port of Bridgeport.
It was once a major shipbuilding center.
But now most of the waterfront is an abandoned toxic brown field.
Development plans have been on the drawing board for 10 years.
Calderon dispatches the truckers who pick up pallets of bananas and pineapples that come by boat from Columbia and Costa Rica and are transported all over the U.S.
and Canada.
I call it the banana boat because we have the company over there.
You can't see her in the fog but (unintelligible) and they bring a boat with 200,000 bananas every week or more.
What are you picking up?
Do you know?
Yeah.
Bananas.
When you see her at her job, she is definitely in control, business-like but warm and personable.
You're going to go to the warehouse on my left.
See Eric(ph), he'll tell you what door to back into after you are loaded.
Come back here and sign out.
Okay.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
Seeing her directing the truckers, you would never guess her own struggles.
Her job has been cut back to 30 hours a week.

Her salary of $21,000 a year doesn't cover rent, electricity and the expenses of taking care of her eleven-year-old grandson, not to mention paying $160-a-month for eight medications for diabetes and heart disease.
I have to decide whether I want to get my prescriptions or buy food for the table.
How often do you see a doctor?
Well, I go when I get real sick.
She wanted to see me every two weeks because she says that I'm a ticking bomb.
But it's a $20 co-pay.
Calderon had run out of her medicines two weeks earlier.
Although she got a paycheck the day after I spoke to her, all that money was earmarked for urgent bills.
So I won't be able to get my medicine this week.
Calderon is often short of breath.
She can't walk long distances.
She has no car.
And when a coworker can't drive her to work, she has to rely on Bridgeport's less than adequate system of public transportation.
Marilyn Ondrasik is the executive director of the Bridgeport Child Advocacy Coalition.
She says 43 percent of the families in Calderon's neighborhood earn less than $20,000-a-year, and yet the other Connecticut is right next door.
You can drive a mile from right here and you can see folks whose incomes are well over $100,000 a year.
And you can see all of the opportunities and advantages and lifestyles that they have, and the suburbs have put up walls.

And some of the working poor like Calderon are convinced that city officials and developers would like nothing more than to drive out poor families and bring in young college-educated elites as has happened in Connecticut cities like Norwalk.
They think we are pests, that the working poor are pests.
(Soundbite of music)
What is it?
The tale of two cities.
Anthony Bennett is the senior pastor of the Mount Aery Baptist Church in Bridgeport, a very diverse congregation.
On a weekday summer morning, the place is bustling with music and an academic camp for kids.
The church also runs programs for racial awareness, and Reverend Bennett is convinced that racism is at the root of some of Bridgeport's problems.
Perhaps if the color - the skin color - of the persons were a little different and more reflective of Fairfield County, some of the issues will be addressed I believe much differently.
Given the conditions in Bridgeport, Bennett sees activism as more important than prayer.
Perhaps the perception is we're talking about praising the Lord, going to heaven.
No, you know - God will take care of the sweet by and by.
We want to help in the nasty now and now.
The churches like Rev.
Bennett's are definitely picking up some of the pieces.
But the jury is still out on whether the attempt to revive and develop Bridgeport will help the working poor get ahead.
Margot Adler, NPR News.
This is Talk of the Nation, I'm Neal Conan broadcasting today from the studios of WVTF and Radio IQ in Roanoke, Virginia.
There's an audience of about 30 people with us here in the studio.
Thank you all for coming.
I appreciate your coming.
(Soundbite of applause)
We're only about 250 miles from our usual home in studio 3A, but the difference has to be measured in more than miles.

Roanoke is in the middle of Appalachia, a part of the country known for its physical beauty, a point not lost us as we drove west to the Blue Ridge Mountains and then south through the Shenandoah Valley.
We could dwell on that for quite a while especially as the trees here start to turn.

But today, we want to talk about the people who live here and by that we mean a huge swath of the eastern United States, people here are known as Appalachians, mountain people, and by a few other names that maybe aren't so flattering.
We want to hear from Appalachians today about how you see yourselves?
How do you connect to the history of the region?
How did the mountains shape you?
Our number 800-989-8255, email us talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.

Later in the program we're going to hear some of the stories that people here in Roanoke are telling in the story core van that's visiting here, but first Appalachians on Appalachia and we'll begin on the phones.
And let's go to Beth.
Beth with us from Huntington, in West Virginia.
Hi.
This is Beth.
Go ahead please, you're on the air.
Have a great day.
Bye.
Well, are you negotiating with the protestors?

I think we share a sense that, as individuals, this is - Americans are great people, but as a country right now, we've allowed ourselves to back into a corner that it's going to take a long while to get out of.
And you can't get elected to any office by saying that it's going to take years to fix a problem, and that more people are going to lose their houses, and jobs aren't going to come back right away.
But I think, realistically, anyone who's paying attention, they can't see the end of this, and I think that's what I share with everybody.
And you don't see an end.
I don't see a realistic end.
I see a - I suppose we could prop things up again, but eventually...
(Soundbite of laughter)
